# Arpeggio: Minor 7th in D# (Shape: G)

An arpeggio is a musical technique where the notes of a chord are played individually rather than simultaneously. The Minor 7th arpeggio in D# (Eâ™­) is a combination of the notes D#, F#, A#, and C#. It is commonly referred to as a Minor 7th chord and is played using the G shape on the guitar. 

## Notes of the Arpeggio
- D# (Root)
- F# (Minor 3rd)
- A# (Perfect 5th)
- C# (Minor 7th)

## Intervals
- Root to Minor 3rd: Minor 3rd (3 semitones)
- Root to Perfect 5th: Perfect 5th (7 semitones)
- Root to Minor 7th: Minor 7th (10 semitones)

## Musical Flavor and Usage
The Minor 7th arpeggio in D# adds a melancholic and jazzy flavor to music. It is often used in jazz, blues, R&B, and soul genres to create a smooth and sophisticated sound. This arpeggio can evoke feelings of introspection and introspection, making it a popular choice for emotional ballads and expressive solos.

## Songs Using the Minor 7th Arpeggio in D#
1. **"Autumn Leaves"** by Joseph Kosma - This jazz standard features the Minor 7th arpeggio extensively in its chord progression, creating a rich and colorful harmonic texture.
   
2. **"All of Me"** by John Legend - The Minor 7th arpeggio in D# is used in this soulful ballad to add depth and emotion to the chord changes, enhancing the heartfelt lyrics of the song.
   
3. **"Stormy Monday"** by T-Bone Walker - This blues classic showcases the Minor 7th arpeggio in D# in its soulful guitar solos, highlighting the expressive and moody nature of the chord.
